quotes.topic_title: Brand meaning grows beyond the name
quotes.text: So over time, a word can come to mean something that is beyond what that actual word means.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: A mental model for brand-building: meaning accrues through repeated associations over time, not just the literal name.

quotes.topic_title: Brand meaning grows beyond the name
quotes.text: Like Disney means magic today. Volvo means safety.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Concrete examples showing how brands can “own” an attribute that becomes synonymous with the company.

quotes.topic_title: Brand meaning grows beyond the name
quotes.text: So that's kind of what I mean, that the name is just part of the overall marketing or the overall brand and a bad name with a really great company with great company strategy, great marketing is going to be great over time.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Actionable prioritization: focus on company strategy and marketing execution over obsessing about naming perfection.

quotes.topic_title: Brand meaning grows beyond the name
quotes.text: And a good name is just going to help you, but I don't think a bad name is going to kill a good company.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Counterintuitive takeaway that challenges the common belief that a “bad” name dooms a product.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Arielle Jackson spent nine years at Google, where she helped grow Gmail in its early days, taking it from just a side project to a product that is now used by hundreds of millions of people all over the world.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete example of scaling a product from an internal side project to massive global adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Then she went on to Square, where she was one of the first marketers and helped launch and scale the growth of Square reader.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Points to an early-stage go-to-market role where brand and growth work directly shaped a flagship product launch.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: She's also worked with over 100 early stage companies, helping them nail their brand and marketing efforts, including Patreon, Loom, Front, Eero, Maven, Sprig, just to name a few.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a credibility/data point (100+ startups) and specific examples that signal repeatable brand-building patterns across companies.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our chat, we cover primarily three things, naming strategies for your startup or your product, a framework for developing your brand, that includes your purpose, your positioning, and your personality, and also getting PR for your startup.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces an actionable brand strategy framework (purpose, positioning, personality) plus practical areas (naming, PR).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Based on our data, about a third of people will consider switching to another company after just one bad experience during onboarding.
quotes.speaker: Ashley
quotes.context: Quantifies how a single onboarding failure can materially increase churn risk, making onboarding quality a retention lever.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I'm consistently seeing that improving onboarding is one of the highest leverage opportunities for both signup conversion and increasing long-term retention.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical prioritization heuristic: treat onboarding improvements as a high-ROI growth and retention investment.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Getting people to your aha moment more quickly and reliably is so incredibly important.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A clear product-led growth mental model: optimize onboarding around accelerating time-to-value (“aha moment”).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: According to AngelList head of product, banking makes every single feature more interesting. With it, our platform functions as financial mission control for our customers. Without it, we're just another software tool in a big messy stack.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Illustrates a differentiation strategy: embedding financial primitives can transform a product from a tool into a central system of record/control.

quotes.topic_title: Favorite project: launching Square Stand hardware
quotes.text: It was the first time I ever worked on hardware and our joint Square was 140 people. We had no marketing function. We had a couple marketing people. We had no product managers and the hardware team was running the show on launching this new product that was supposed to get us up market into brick and mortar.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Highlights an early-stage operating model where cross-functional gaps force unconventional ownership—and the strategic goal of moving upmarket.

quotes.topic_title: Favorite project: launching Square Stand hardware
quotes.text: I volunteered to run the launch of this product as a product marketer for the first time.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: A concrete career and execution tactic: stepping into a new function by taking ownership of a high-impact launch.

quotes.topic_title: Favorite project: launching Square Stand hardware
quotes.text: We had people fly around the country and get cool coffee shops and brick and mortar businesses seeding it so that they would all use it.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Describes a practical go-to-market method: seeding a product in influential venues to create real-world proof and visibility.

quotes.topic_title: Favorite project: launching Square Stand hardware
quotes.text: We had I think 15 Metro areas covered with the coolest coffee shops and donut shops and everything at launch.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: A specific rollout example (15 metro areas) showing how to scale seeding beyond a single flagship location.

quotes.topic_title: Favorite project: launching Square Stand hardware
quotes.text: And you know, there was a lot of fake it till you make it. I was negotiating a deal with Best Buy in the Apple store. Never done anything like that before.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Captures a counterintuitive execution reality: doing high-stakes retail/channel work without prior experience and learning by doing.

quotes.topic_title: Square Stand positioning and target customer
quotes.text: And the positioning was really that it was for brick and mortar businesses, particularly quick serve coffee, donuts, sandwich shops that kind of quick serve brick and mortars.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Shows the importance of narrowing positioning to a specific, high-fit customer segment rather than a broad market.

quotes.topic_title: Square Stand positioning and target customer
quotes.text: And it was up against your ugly old point of sale. Your cash register effectively. That was our foil.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Demonstrates a clear competitive foil to sharpen messaging and make differentiation instantly legible.

quotes.topic_title: Square Stand positioning and target customer
quotes.text: And the benefit was turn your iPad into a point of sale.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: A concise benefit statement that translates product capability into an immediately understandable customer outcome.

quotes.topic_title: Square Stand positioning and target customer
quotes.text: And the differentiator was about one unified experience that you can do everything you can on your cash register and more, and you'd be proud to have it out on your counter.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Highlights a positioning model that combines functional parity-plus with emotional/design value (“pride-of-place”) for physical retail environments.

quotes.topic_title: From jewelry maker to Square marketer
quotes.text: And then I got a Square reader and I sold at a craft fair that year. And it was awesome. That Square reader, it helped people buy more, it helped me sort of look cool. It was just really great to accept credit cards. I'd never done it before.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Highlights how improving the buying experience (and even perceived professionalism) can directly increase conversion in real-world selling.

quotes.topic_title: From jewelry maker to Square marketer
quotes.text: I used to take PayPal invoices and be on my computer and send someone an invoice and they'd get it. It was painful. All the reasons that people use Square, I experienced it.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Shows the value of firsthand customer pain as a practical method for understanding product-market fit and messaging.

quotes.topic_title: From jewelry maker to Square marketer
quotes.text: I sold I think it was 50% more than I did last year because I accepted credit cards
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: A concrete data point illustrating how adding a payment method can materially lift sales.

quotes.topic_title: From jewelry maker to Square marketer
quotes.text: Having been a merchant, I think it helped me understand the small merchant that initially we were marketing to.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Emphasizes that doing the job of your customer can sharpen marketing empathy and targeting.

quotes.topic_title: First Round marketer-in-residence role explained
quotes.text: And instead I just decided I was going to help a bunch of other small startups. And I emailed a few friends from past lives who had small startups, which was like, Hey, I'm not going to Twitter with the rest of the team. You do need marketing help. And every single person wrote back and said, yes. And that's basically how I started consulting.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable way to bootstrap consulting demand: directly ask your network and validate need fast.

quotes.topic_title: First Round marketer-in-residence role explained
quotes.text: we did a three month project for one day a week, nine years ago. And I'm still there. I work halftime at First Round.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Shows a practical model for starting small (time-boxed, part-time) and growing into a long-term embedded role.

quotes.topic_title: First Round marketer-in-residence role explained
quotes.text: So the way it works is if you're funded by First Round and as part of your onboarding, we offer a lot of value add services and I'm one of them.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Highlights an operator-friendly “platform services” approach: bake expert support into onboarding rather than ad hoc help later.

quotes.topic_title: First Round marketer-in-residence role explained
quotes.text: And what that means when you're a seed stage startup is everything from naming to positioning, to developing a brand identity, a website and your initial launch, and eventually hiring a marketer.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: A clear scope checklist for seed-stage marketing work, from fundamentals (naming/positioning) through launch and hiring.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a good startup name
quotes.text: And I personally tend to like those kinds of names that are suggestive or evocative, where when I tell you what the company does, you're like, oh, that makes sense. But it's not that what the name is tells you exactly what the company does.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Arielle gives a practical naming heuristic: aim for names that “click” after explanation without being purely descriptive.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a good startup name
quotes.text: It also has a little bit of emotion to it. It has some nostalgia. It's fun to say it's short, it's memorable. I think all of those things make a good name.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: She lists concrete, usable criteria founders can apply when evaluating candidate names.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a good startup name
quotes.text: My take on empty vessel names is they can be really memorable and they can be evocative of the emotion, but you have to do a lot more marketing work over time to make it mean something.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: A clear tradeoff model for “nonsense/empty vessel” names: memorability upside, but higher long-term brand-building cost.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a good startup name
quotes.text: If there is a meaning behind your name, your name is doing a little bit more of your marketing work for you.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: A simple mental model for why suggestive/evocative names can be strategically advantageous.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a good startup name
quotes.text: My personal preference is if you think about there's descriptive names, the Internet Explorer, there's suggestive names like Chrome, then there's evocative names, which I would say Seesaw and Maven fit into there where they're like in between suggestive and evocative, and then there's empty vessel names or fanciful names. There's a spectrum.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: She offers a practical taxonomy founders can use to structure brainstorming and align on what kind of name they want.

quotes.topic_title: Naming process: brief, criteria, brainstorm
quotes.text: Yeah. So the first thing is to do your product positioning. I really believe that positioning dictates so much of your marketing and should always be the first thing you do.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Establishes a clear sequencing rule: do positioning before naming (and even before other build work) because it drives downstream marketing decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Naming process: brief, criteria, brainstorm
quotes.text: And then there are seven criteria for names that always apply in my opinion.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Introduces a repeatable evaluation framework teams can use to systematically judge name candidates beyond gut feel.

quotes.topic_title: Naming process: brief, criteria, brainstorm
quotes.text: So I generally stay away from naming trends, because I want your company named not to sound dated in 10 or 20 years.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: A practical heuristic that challenges trendy naming conventions by optimizing for long-term brand timelessness.

quotes.topic_title: Naming process: brief, criteria, brainstorm
quotes.text: I always say a good name is only going to help you, but a bad name won't hurt a good company.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: A counterintuitive perspective that reduces over-optimization anxiety in naming by reframing its impact relative to product/company strength.

quotes.topic_title: Naming process: brief, criteria, brainstorm
quotes.text: And the idea is we spend one hour, I set it up beforehand and we try to come up with hundreds and hundreds of bad ideas and a couple decent ones that are worth exploring more.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: A concrete brainstorming methodology: time-boxed session designed to generate volume (including bad ideas) to surface a shortlist of viable options.

quotes.topic_title: Product vs company naming and brand equity
quotes.text: The only difference is if you have a lot of equity in your company name... Square is a good example. Square had a lot of equity. Google is a perfect example.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Sets up the key decision variable in naming: how much brand equity already exists in the master brand.

quotes.topic_title: Product vs company naming and brand equity
quotes.text: A lot of equity in the company name, you often don't want to name your products something really creative and different because you actually want the equity in the master brand to come through.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: leverage the parent brand by keeping product names aligned rather than overly novel.

quotes.topic_title: Product vs company naming and brand equity
quotes.text: So if you think about Square's names, they have other ones, when they diverge from the Square brand like cash or when they want something new or Google, when they came out with Android and they wanted to diverge from the master brand.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Provides concrete examples of when to intentionally diverge from the master brand to create a distinct identity.

quotes.topic_title: Product vs company naming and brand equity
quotes.text: But think about all the products. Square Register, Square Stand, Square App, Google Maps, they're really boring and it's because the equity is in the company name and the product name can actually be boring and descriptive.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Counterintuitive takeaway: “boring” descriptive product names can be optimal when the company brand carries the equity.

quotes.topic_title: Bad names rarely kill great companies
quotes.text: So over time a word can come to mean something that is beyond what that actual word means.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Reframes naming as something brand-building can transform over time, reducing the need for a “perfect” initial meaning.

quotes.topic_title: Bad names rarely kill great companies
quotes.text: Disney means magic today. Volvo means safety. Those names are not good. If I just put it in a spreadsheet or one of those lists, no one would pick it.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Uses concrete examples to show how strong companies imbue ordinary names with powerful associations.

quotes.topic_title: Bad names rarely kill great companies
quotes.text: So that's kind of what I mean that the name is just part of the overall marketing or the overall brand and a bad name with a really great company with great company strategy, great marketing is going to be great over time. And a good name is just going to help you, but I don't think a bad name is going to kill a good company.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Actionable prioritization: focus on strategy and marketing over obsessing about naming perfection.

quotes.topic_title: Bad names rarely kill great companies
quotes.text: You give people a name like that and it's like, you have to imagine what it could be.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Highlights a common evaluation trap—judging names as static spreadsheet entries rather than as brands that will be built.

quotes.topic_title: Bad names rarely kill great companies
quotes.text: You want to avoid those, but if you come up with something that is pretty good and you can make up something beautiful out of it and it fits your company, it does some of the marketing work for you and people like to say it and ideally it's memorable and it has some emotion to it, go, go for it.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Practical selection criteria: aim for “pretty good” plus fit, memorability, emotion, and sayability rather than chasing trends or perfection.

quotes.topic_title: Common naming mistake and First Round value-add
quotes.text: I really believe in using a code name that's so ridiculous that you won't ever launch a product like that if you're just trying to incorporate and go really quick.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Actionable naming tactic: pick an intentionally absurd placeholder to avoid getting emotionally attached to a weak early name.

quotes.topic_title: Common naming mistake and First Round value-add
quotes.text: If you pick something so ridiculous that you would never launch, it's actually helpful because then you can go through a process and find a name that will do more of your work for you and you won't be attached to something crappy.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Counterintuitive mental model: a “bad on purpose” code name creates freedom to later choose a name that carries more brand/positioning load.

quotes.topic_title: Common naming mistake and First Round value-add
quotes.text: And I recently couldn't take on an outsider First Round project and referred it to them. It's $47,000 for a name.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Concrete data point on the real cost of professional naming help, useful for budgeting and evaluating in-house vs. external support.

quotes.topic_title: Brand strategy framework: purpose, positioning, personality
quotes.text: your brand is who people think you are.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Reframes brand away from visuals and toward perception, which is what strategy should aim to shape.

quotes.topic_title: Brand strategy framework: purpose, positioning, personality
quotes.text: developing a brand strategy is what do you want to be? What do you want people to think you are? And what are you going to do to help shape that perception?
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: A practical definition of brand strategy as an explicit plan to create a desired perception.

quotes.topic_title: Brand strategy framework: purpose, positioning, personality
quotes.text: I like to start with, why do you do what you do? Just having a really clear understanding of that. That's your purpose. The second part is your product positioning. So meaning how do you want people to understand your product and what role it plays in their lives? And then the last part is your personality, which is how do you show up in the world?
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: A startup-friendly 3-part framework (purpose, positioning, personality) that teams can use to build brand foundations before design.

quotes.topic_title: Brand strategy framework: purpose, positioning, personality
quotes.text: It's not the logo.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: A punchy reminder—supported by the Volvo example—that brand meaning is created by decisions and behavior, not visual identity.

quotes.topic_title: Brand strategy framework: purpose, positioning, personality
quotes.text: they came out with the three point safety harness and instead of patenting it and licensing it, they gave that away for free for everyone because that would make all the world's cars safer and those kinds of company decisions. That's what made Volvo stand for safety.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: A concrete example of how brand positioning is earned through company actions that reinforce purpose.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I kind of like to think of it as a safety net for my nutrition in case I've missed something in my diet.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A simple mental model for positioning a daily habit/product as risk-reduction rather than perfection.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Two, they treat AG1 like a software product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable methodology: apply software-style iteration and continuous improvement to a physical product.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Apparently they're on their 52nd iteration and they're constantly evolving it based on latest science research studies and internal testing that they do.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example and data point that reinforces rapid iteration as a competitive advantage.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: There's no need for a million different pills and supplements to look out for your health. Make it easy.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable advice to reduce friction by consolidating complexity into one repeatable daily action.

quotes.topic_title: Brand work timing and defining purpose well
quotes.text: If you're starting from nothing, I think you can do this in three weeks.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Sets a concrete, surprisingly short timeline for early-stage brand strategy work, making it feel tractable.

quotes.topic_title: Brand work timing and defining purpose well
quotes.text: And I think whatever time it takes you actually is going to save you so much time down the road.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Reframes brand strategy as a time-saving investment that speeds up downstream execution and decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Brand work timing and defining purpose well
quotes.text: I just want one thing because people can only remember one thing and it's your purpose and it's why you do what you do.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: A memorable simplification: prioritize a single, recallable purpose over multiple abstract brand artifacts.

quotes.topic_title: Brand work timing and defining purpose well
quotes.text: So you can introduce yourself at a conference. You're the keynote speaker at a conference and I want you to introduce yourself and I want you to go, hi, I'm Lenny, I'm the founder of the company X, and we exist to blah and say it and have that feel natural.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Provides a practical “conference intro” test for whether a purpose statement is clear, natural, and usable.

quotes.topic_title: Brand work timing and defining purpose well
quotes.text: And the other thing it should be able to do is be the header for your about page.
quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.context: Gives a second concrete usability test: the purpose should double as high-level website messaging.
